SAN FRANCISCO = Rev. Mar
tin Luther King criticized FBl
Chief ]. Edgar Hoover for say
ing Communists have infiltrated
the American civil rights move
ment.


"Mr. Hoover has allowed him
self to aid and abet the sala-
cious claims of Southern racists
and extreme right wing ele-
ments,' the Rev. Mr.. King said
in reference to Hoover state
ment made public Tuesday.


Hoover told a closed session
of the house Apr OPERATIONS sub
committee Jan. % that Com
munist influence does exist In
the Negro movement


King challenged Hoover Ito
come forward and provide real
evidence

FBI Head S
Red Cha rye

'Where The Jobs Are is
the theme of the second annual.
Youth Employment Seminar. Sat-,
May 2 co-spons ored by the Ari-
iona State Employment Service
and the Urban League. 1t will
be held in the First Congrega-
tional Church auditorium. l4O7
North Second Street, noon to $3.50
pm. The workshop will present
tips on summer job possibilities,
filling applications, and interview
techniques.


Keynote speaker will be Jeff
Thomas. personnel manager of
International Business Machine
Corporation.


Group advisors, will be
Charles Frenald, Safeway Stores;
Robert Foley, Arizona State En-
ployment Farm Labor Office;
Madison Western, Montgomery
Ward.

Job Sem inur
Set May End

NEW YORK The United States
''has a major responsibility to
take the lead in invoking eco
nomic sanctions against the Union
of South Africa" Closter B. Cur
rent, director of branches of the
National Association for the Ad-
vancement of Colored People,
said upon his return from an in
ternational conference in London.


Current represented the MA
ACP at the London Conference
on Economic Sanctions Against
South Africa, April l4-l7. The
conference was attended by dele
gates and observers from 40
countries throughout the world,
including the major powers as
well as the Iron Curtain coun-
tries.


Chairman of the conference
was Mongi Slim, Foreign Minis
ter of Tunisia, who stated in his
closing speech that the confer
ence "has clearly shown that
economic sanctions are polite
ally necessary, economically
possible and legally valid


Mr.. Current reported to MA
ACP Executive Secretary Roy
Wilkins that the conference had
demonstrated the tragic conse-
quences of apartheid in South
Africa and that unless action
is taken in the near future by
the United Nations Security Coun-
ell to impose economic sanctions
on the country, there is grave
danger of war;

A. Maceo Walker, Sr., prom
inent Negro businessman of
Memphis, Tenn, is representing
the United States at the first
American Exposition in Bamako,
Mali, April lS-May 10, the US.
Department of Commerce an
nounced today. Mr.. Walker is
president and chairman of the
board of Universal Life Insur-
ance Co., Memphis.


Born in Indianola, Miss, he
is a graduate of Fisk University
in Nashville, Tenn, and did grad
uate work at New York Universe
ty and the University of Michi-
gan and in 1859 received an hon
orary Doctor of Humanities de-
gree from Wherefore Universe
ty in Ohio.


Mr.. Walker is also president,
and co-founder with his father,
of the Tri-State Bank of Mem
phis. He is president of Memphis
Mortgage Guaranty Co., and is a
member of the board of direc-
tors of the Memphis Chamber
of Commerce.


In 1916, Mr.. Walker was cited
by President Truman for signif-
icant leadership in the war onin-
flation. He has also been cited by
the National Urban League for
outstanding achievement in bus
mess.

Sent To Trade Meet

!, There are many reasons a0hy a county jun
ioy college district is feasible and ne cess02y
in Mayicobo County. More and more high
school graduates are deprived Of gaining more
knowledge and skillS which would enable them
to secure better jobs witlaout attending four
year college or university.


Many graduates from high school cannot
afford to attend college or university and
thew could be Included in a wen rounded jun
iOy college program.


There are presently more than 5000 stu
dents in the MaYicOba County Junior College
District. Buildings being used are no'O rented
and facilities are inadequate. The rent fees
amount to almost quarter Of million dol
lars.


= Approving the proposed Junior College Conn
ty bond issue a0tll by0vide J1'adS to purchase
sites, erect buildings and buy Phoenix College.
Three locations for Junior colleges mould in
crease the educational opportunities for the
eveygyoaUirzg number of students aOko graduate
from high school each year.


3 The election Will be held Saturday, May Z.
Ballots may be cast at any high school IN the
county and at Phoenix College.

pha Chi Pi Omega sorority will
sponsor it's annual hair show
"Leap Year Coiffures," Sum-,
May 3, 4 pm. at Eastlake Park
auditorium. Donation ST.. For
ticket information call Mrs. Le-
berta Ray at AL 2-93l3 or
AL 3-55l6.

SOUTH AFRICA
SHOULD BE PUNISHED
full articles.article:

nomic sanctions against the Union

possible and legally valid

Africa and that unless action

ell to impose economic sanctions
